awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Chronology and Ecology of Late Pleistocene Megafauna at Rancho La Brea
awd_abstract_narration:
The Rancho La Brea tar pits of Los Angeles, California contain thousands of bones from large mammals --dire wolves, sabertooth cats, coyotes, extinct bison, horses, and others-- trapped in sticky surface oil deposits during the last Ice Age. This unparalleled fossil assemblage allows rigorous studies of extinct mammal biology, especially of carnivores which are rare at most fossil sites. The La Brea fossils span a critical time in Earth's history (approximately 50,000 years ago to the present) that includes major events such as the end of the last Ice Age, the arrival of humans in North America, and an extinction that killed two thirds of the large mammals on the continent. This unique deposit will be used to investigate relationships between major environmental changes and evolutionary variation (size, diet, etc.) in large mammals, information that is critical for promoting the survival of wildlife today. The project involves significant community outreach in the greater Los Angeles area through the Tar Pits Museum and will create educational content that will be available online for high school teachers across the country.

	The major impediment to system-level study at Rancho La Brea is a paucity of radiocarbon dates and the resulting inability to correlate biotic change with time. This project will intensively radiocarbon date samples from multiple pits spanning the last 50,000 years to establish the first detailed chronology for the entrapment of four extinct species of large mammals, and one extant species. It will involve the collection and compilation of census data for these species to track changes in total abundance and diversity, as well as data on morphological and dietary changes. A well-resolved chronology will allow these data on evolutionary changes in mammals and the Pleistocene megafaunal extinctions to be linked to existing records of major paleo-environmental changes. This work will have broad implications for our understanding of extinctions, survival, environmental variables, and humans on mammalian ecology, which is directly relevant to modern conservation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: La Brea Tar Pits and Museum

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF award was designed to increase our understanding about the large mammals that abruptly went extinct at the end of the Late Pleistocene or Ice Age about 12,000 years ago, by studying the fossils at the Rancho La Brea Tar Pits. One of our most important outcomes was radiocarbon dating over 400 specimens, doubling the prior amount, across several deposits or “pits,” including five species of large mammals, both carnivores and herbivores. Dating tells us when these animals lived, and determines the period of time that a given pit entrapped animals. From the same specimens, we also collected isotope data which informs us about what those animals were consuming and where in the local region they were found, and even gives us information about potential migration. Finally, we collected data on a much larger sample of tens of thousands of fossils, including measurements of fossil bones and teeth, and taphonomy which tells us about the environmental conditions when those animals were buried and fossilized. We were then able to compare our data with changes in climate, and data about local plants, to look at trends across the thousands of years which occurred before and through the extinction. 

  We’ve already discovered several important results from this work. Our team published three papers, the most significant of which was in Science magazine, and covered by national press, that showed an important driver of the megafaunal extinction at Ranch La Brea appears to be fire, most likely from humans living in the region at the time. We showed how plant fossils, sediment and charcoal, along with other climate records support our hypothesis that naturally-caused, increasingly warm temperatures in drying surroundings resulted in a tinderbox for humans who used fire. This led to massive fire events, which affected large animals more than smaller ones (many of which survived the extinction event). This demonstrates the consequences of climate change, and even relates to our modern conditions, in which we also see warming climate and fires in our region. The data also allowed us to more accurately determine the time of the extinction. In addition, we published papers on isotopes from teeth and fossil bones in sabertooth cats, dire wolves and coyotes demonstrating potential differences in their diets, and also on toothwear in herbivores which demonstrated different dietary strategies in bison, camels and horses. A number of other important related projects are still in process, including a paper that focuses on individual pits which will demonstrate that most of them represent different time frames, which has been widely debated and could not be resolved without our new radiocarbon dates across many pits. This paper will further provide future researchers with more accurate parameters about the fossils within the largest pits at Rancho La Brea. We are also working on papers that analyze changes in coyotes over this period of time, which is of note as coyotes represent the rare large species that survived the extinction. We have other projects that are still being analyzed now. In total our work contributes to a fuller and more accurate understanding of the large extinct mammals that dominated Southern California, and why they died out (or didn’t).

Finally, our work engaged students in research and learning, and the public in terms of information about our work. We worked with 11 undergraduate students over 6 years, who were trained in data collection and analysis, presented their work at local and national conferences and participated in research for 1-2 years, along with one 6-week paid summer internship. In 2018-2020 students worked with museum staff to present some of their work in the galleries to the public at the Tar Pits Museum. During the Covid-19 pandemic, they instead had virtual live sessions with elementary school classes with museum loan materials. Our outreach with high school students and teachers in Tennessee and Iowa was led by faculty who live in those areas, and a couple of students from their universities also traveled to the Tar Pits Museum for summer work. Finally, the museum is using our data as part of a display for the upcoming renovation, and thus museum visitors can learn about our work when they tour the museum.

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2024
Modified by: Wendy J Binder
